section.title: Maven dependency configuration
section.para: To use the Seam Faces module, you need to put the API and implementation JARs on the classpath of your web application. Most of the features of Seam Faces are enabled automatically when it's added to the classpath. Some extra configuration, covered below, is required if you are not using a Servlet 3-compliant container.
If you are using Maven as your build tool, you can add the following single dependency to your pom.xml file to include Seam Faces:

tip.para: Substitute the expression ${seam.faces.version} with the most recent or appropriate version of Seam Faces. Alternatively, you can create a Maven user-defined property to satisfy this substitution so you can centrally manage the version.

section.para: Alternatively, you can use the API at compile time and only include the implementation at runtime. This protects you from inadvertently depending on an implementation class.
In a Servlet 3.0 or Java EE 6 environment, your configuration is now complete!

section.title: How to setup JSF in a Java EE 6 webapp
section.para: Seam Faces requires a working JSF 2.0 configuration. To get a working JSF 2.0 environment in a Java EE 6 environment, you need one of the following:

listitem.para: Bundle the seam-faces jar in your web-app (this sets up jsf for you)
if not #1, you need empty faces-config.xml, where the root element must be present.
if not #1 or #2, you need a web.xml with the Faces Servlet defined.

section.para: The JBoss JSF documentation provides further details on #2 and #3 above, but these steps are unnecessary when you use Seam Faces (#1). this is because Seam Faces scans for the presence of the Seam Servlet, and programatically registers it for you if it's not present.
